channel.title: Cooperation on Baltic Security Foundation
channel.description: Recent content in Cooperation on Baltic Security Foundation

item.title: University Book Donation
item.description: The Baltic Security Foundation team shares their most recent books to universities around the world to promote the studies of regional security.

item.title: NATO Summit 2021: Broad Goals, Few Specifics
item.description: On June 14, heads of state from all NATO members met in Brussels for the 2021 NATO summit.

item.title: Ukraine-Baltic Energy Cooperation in the Context of Russian Hybrid Aggression
item.description: This article provided by our Ukrainian partners, Ad Astra Despite being different in so many aspects, Ukraine and the Baltic states have always had a lot of things in common, the main one being a troublesome neighbor on the eastern border that we all have to deal with.

item.title: U.S.-Poland Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement and Why It Matters
item.description: Introduction On November 9, 2020, 31 years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, Polish President Andrzej Duda signed the Polish Senate’s ratification bill of the U.

item.title: Much Ado About Something: 2% Defense Expenditures and What Really Matters
item.description: In 2014, NATO member states agreed to target defense expenditures of two percent of gross domestic product (GDP) by 2024.

item.title: Spring Storm Exercises Demonstrate Ongoing Commitment to Deterrence, Readiness
item.description: Each year, Estonia hosts Spring Storm (Kevadtorm), bringing together forces from all across NATO to conduct field and live-fire exercises.

item.title: The Three Seas Initiative
item.description: Last month, U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced that the United States would commit up to $1 Billion in support for the Three Seas Initiative.

item.title: Interoperability at Sea
item.description: Last week, Finland and Sweden conducted naval cooperation exercises in the Baltic Sea.

item.title: Defending the Suwałki Gap
item.description: At the end of last month, Lithuania and Poland announced that the two countries would each assign a brigade to NATO Headquarters in Poland to “train and act together” for the defense of the Suwałki Gap.
